commit_message:
Fix blueprints and specs link in ocata template

In I2a178966b65f628d5752c5327aeda8b625f190ba,
the blueprints and specs link was fixed in mitaka-template.rst.
It should also be applied for ocata-template.rst

TrivialFix
Change-Id: Idfdbaf732e46b94f11650e714ca439812bcd83cf

commit_message:
Revert "Workaround DHCP agent gate issues"

This reverts commit 1a765d7afd3a37f4dd6eb6362705a425a7764e6b
now that bug 1624079 is resolved.

Change-Id: I69645d93cae74d0327891ce1dc713461b6ab83ad
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/networking-ovn refs/changes/29/375729/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # layer-3 is enabled. So for consistency, regardless of the layer-3 # support, the conventional DHCP agent will be forced to provide # metadata for all networks. iniset $Q_DHCP_CONF_FILE DEFAULT force_metadata True
deleted_lines: # layer-3 is enabled. For consistency it would be nice to always force # conventional DHCP agent to provide metadata for all networks regardless # of the layer-3 support. However, this cannot be done until bug/1624079 # is fixed. if [[ "$OVN_L3_MODE" == "True" ]]; then iniset $Q_DHCP_CONF_FILE DEFAULT force_metadata True fi

commit_message:
Add 'More Actions...' Actions

This patch adds actions named 'More Actions...' that for each resource type
redirects to the resource's legacy details page.  This is achieved through
a redirect action service that is added just like any other action to the
resource's item action list.

Adds:
* Instances
* Volumes
* Volume Snapshots
* Networks
* Subnets
* Ports
* Routers
* Hypervisors

Change-Id: I6e6bb3ac6511cef7b8397db4a6517dd209992616
Partially-Implements: blueprint sl-ui-use-hz-registry

commit_message:
Add c-vol,c-bak on subnode when c-api enabled

Cinder is not installed on primary node in Ironic jobs. When c-vol,c-bak
were added to MY_ENABLED_SERVICES on subnode it caused ironic multinode
job to failure. This patch adds c-vol,c-bak to enabled_services only
when c-api is enabled on primary node.

Reference:
[0] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/327619/

Co-Authored-By: Vladyslav Drok <vdrok@mirantis.com>
Change-Id: I7807fe5f76d9fa8b778371299d177cb0bfafc78b
Closes-Bug: #1611381
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack-gate refs/changes/09/352909/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: MY_ENABLED_SERVICES="n-cpu,ceilometer-acompute,dstat" # NOTE(vsaienko) Ironic jobs do not install cinder on primary node if [[ "$DEVSTACK_GATE_IRONIC" -eq '0' ]]; then MY_ENABLED_SERVICES+=",c-vol,c-bak" fi

subject: tox: Install like other OpenStack projects
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-09-27 14:00:43.000000000', 'files': ['tools/tox_install.sh', 'tox.ini'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/kuryr/commit/e17ecd5b45a858fcb6e9d6a49a7c8c6d1ab15fb9', 'message': 'tox: Install like other OpenStack projects

We had tools/tox_install.sh for the case we could depend on neutron
which was not on pypi. In the end, we depend only on
python-neutronclient and as such, this workaround is not necessary and
only makes tox slower.

Change-Id: I2df023d97dfb6bbd4b987e98a42b548fc498b237
Signed-off-by: Antoni Segura Puimedon <antonisp@celebdor.com>
'}]
commit_message:
tox: Install like other OpenStack projects

We had tools/tox_install.sh for the case we could depend on neutron
which was not on pypi. In the end, we depend only on
python-neutronclient and as such, this workaround is not necessary and
only makes tox slower.

Change-Id: I2df023d97dfb6bbd4b987e98a42b548fc498b237
Signed-off-by: Antoni Segura Puimedon <antonisp@celebdor.com>

commit_message:
Process OVS trunk bridges associated to VM deletes

If a VM is deleted while the OVS agent is down, upon
restart the OVS trunk bridge is deleted successfully
but the patch ports integration bridge side are left
behind.

This patch makes sure the bridge as well as its peers
are cleaned up.

Closes-bug: #1623708

(cherry picked from commit 4148102f736f7191dd5bf1c2c41505c338c6dc56)

Change-Id: I3f010755fdb6501753d20357ad2cd0d6c02cf22a

subject: Correct fix for IPv6 auto address interfaces
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-09-27 15:19:11.000000000', 'files': ['neutron/common/ipv6_utils.py', 'neutron/tests/unit/agent/linux/test_dhcp.py', 'neutron/agent/linux/dhcp.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/98c4c0876d4df31cf1eb34a2bcc40660e938a2ef', 'message': "Correct fix for IPv6 auto address interfaces

This is a partial revert of d1fb4238306f854ab610204a50c5cdc20ea5c770.
That patch attempted to allow the DHCP agent to manage IPv6 interfaces
to avoid a KeyError in the subnet_interface_map. However, this led
to races with router advertisements and static configuration
(see bug 1627902).

The correct fix was actually a very simple conditional that was broken
because this map shouldn't have been referenced for IPv6 subnets in
the first place. The force metadata option was shortcutting the whole
evaluation so the agent was trying to add a metadata route to a v6
subnet.

This patch undoes the v6 changes from
d1fb4238306f854ab610204a50c5cdc20ea5c770, corrects the conditional,
and adds a simple unit test that ensures the branch doesn't throw
and error.

Closes-Bug: #1624079
Change-Id: Ide494b6333a4f1e279ab58aa27c0aa719e79545d
(cherry picked from commit c0d0986e8b7412f7c37db799177dc529ce9045d2)
"}]
commit_message:
Correct fix for IPv6 auto address interfaces

This is a partial revert of d1fb4238306f854ab610204a50c5cdc20ea5c770.
That patch attempted to allow the DHCP agent to manage IPv6 interfaces
to avoid a KeyError in the subnet_interface_map. However, this led
to races with router advertisements and static configuration
(see bug 1627902).

The correct fix was actually a very simple conditional that was broken
because this map shouldn't have been referenced for IPv6 subnets in
the first place. The force metadata option was shortcutting the whole
evaluation so the agent was trying to add a metadata route to a v6
subnet.

This patch undoes the v6 changes from
d1fb4238306f854ab610204a50c5cdc20ea5c770, corrects the conditional,
and adds a simple unit test that ensures the branch doesn't throw
and error.

Closes-Bug: #1624079
Change-Id: Ide494b6333a4f1e279ab58aa27c0aa719e79545d
(cherry picked from commit c0d0986e8b7412f7c37db799177dc529ce9045d2)

commit_message:
Replace raw_input with input to make PY3 compatible

The raw_input() raises NameError: name 'raw_input'
is not defined in python3. This patch fixes it by
replacing raw_input with input to make PY3 compatible.

Change-Id: I4f76ac7f91c21425c847f0046732399bffc601af

commit_message:
Adding resolv.conf workaround to logging containers

Due to still existing issue in kubernetes and docker with net=host
and mounting kubernetes provided resolve.conf, the workaround needs
to be added logging container running in pods with net=host. Logging
container needs to get ip address of elasticsearch service via dns.

Partially-Implements: blueprint centralized-logging

Change-Id: I83b79a786789ca91427c6f70025b7360f4d0240d

commit_message:
Fix removes duplicated phrase from the document

The duplicated phrase is the following:

Replace items in “%” with the actual values. For example, replace
%RABBITMQ_SERVER_IP% with 127.0.0.1. So, the complete row with the replaced value
will be rabbit_host = 127.0.0.1

Change-Id: I448e4985d657b60843f51e4747be01d7a180c435

commit_message:
Dell SC: ISCSI initialize_connection fixes

The driver could return duplicate iSCSI portal/IQN/Lun combinations.
This patch returns the condensed list.

Also sometimes when Cinder attempts to attach to a volume it will use
the first item in the multipath list rather than the specified single
path entries. So this patch simply moves a known up and active entry
to the front of the list.

Change-Id: Idb371825b6520d4bdb09a1dbb37429cb10643e93
Closes-Bug: #1622703
(cherry picked from commit 4708aa16a7fd43a8fba95b51bf26021498776868)

Add a refreshonly parameter to service_validation

This will allow to run the service_validation on demand when required
from a notification, for example.

commit_message:
Stop logging swiftclient errors

Swiftclient is logging a 404 when looking for
overcloud-without-mergepy.yaml.  To stop this, disable logging
below the critical level for swiftclient.  Note that we catch the
resulting exception from swiftclient and log it ourselves if
necessary, so there's no loss of information in the legitimate
error case.

Change-Id: I24144f3ab2b63c4a0f5fc2c9271e4a51a9ea1353
Closes-Bug: 1626267
(cherry picked from commit 4f9e9597041555c6d0657e9ccf544b781c0f4dcf)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-tripleoclient refs/changes/49/377949/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Swiftclient logs things like 404s at error level, which is a problem # because we use EAFP to check for the existence of files. Turn off # most swiftclient logging to avoid cluttering up our output with # pointless tracebacks. sc_logger = logging.getLogger("swiftclient") sc_logger.setLevel(logging.CRITICAL)

commit_message:
Adding extension for cinder client

Adding block storage extension, to be used in templates for valid
volume ids and volume type ids.

Change-Id: I52c1caa128a60b8f3a7516f11b5d5360e2055d93
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/syntribos refs/changes/38/376638/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright 2016 Intel # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); # you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. # You may obtain a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, # WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. # See the License for the specific language governing permissions and # limitations under the License. from cinderclent.client import Client from oslo_config import cfg from syntribos.extensions.identity import client as id_client from syntribos.utils.memoize import memoize CONF = cfg.CONF def _get_client(): token = id_client.get_scoped_token_v3("user") return Client(endpoint=CONF.syntribos.endpoint, token=token) def create_volume(conn): volume = conn.volumes.create(name="sample_vol", size=1) return volume.id def list_volume_ids(conn): return [volume.id for volume in conn.volumes.list()] @memoize def get_volume_id(): cinder_client = _get_client() volume_ids = list_volume_ids(cinder_client) if not volume_ids: volume_ids.append(create_volume(cinder_client)) return volume_ids[-1]

subject: Fixing inconsistency in Glance store names.
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-09-16 15:31:10.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/glance/commit/2092988c02a2ace0249b6b01bf0c6a60986d87c2', 'message': 'Fixing inconsistency in Glance store names.

The store names used in Glance and glance_store are not in sync with
each other. Converting store names: ``vmware_datastore`` and ``filesystem``
to ``vmware`` and ``file`` respectively to be in sync with glance_store
names and at the same time accommodate backoward compatibility for old
conf files using ``filesystem`` and ``vmware_datastore``.

Change-Id: I3d8593cdae6780ae721afedcf47dd45afa684f25
closes-bug:1615852
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-09-26 18:11:14.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/glance/commit/f0db3fe5aefdfdb7971032be343358dab5e6d30b', 'message': 'Fixing inconsistency in Glance store names.

The store names used in glance and glance_store are not in sync with
each other.

This can confuse operators who have to use different names to refer to
the same store while setting values for configuration options such as
``store_type_preference`` in glance and configuration option like
``store`` in glance_store. This inconsistency may also confuse
developers during code changes, complicating future code changes with
respect to this.

Mapping store names: ``vmware_datastore`` and ``filesystem``
to ``vmware`` and ``file`` respectively to be in sync with glance_store
entry point names and at the same time accommodate backward
compatibility for old configuration files that might still be using
``filesystem`` and ``vmware_datastore``.
Note: This change applies only when multiple image locations are being
used and ``location_strategy`` configuration option is set to
``store_type``.

Note: This change does not require a config refresh change.

Impact:
UpgradeImpact

commit_message:
Fixing inconsistency in Glance store names.

The store names used in glance and glance_store are not in sync with
each other.

This can confuse operators who have to use different names to refer to
the same store while setting values for configuration options such as
``store_type_preference`` in glance and configuration option like
``store`` in glance_store. This inconsistency may also confuse
developers during code changes, complicating future code changes with
respect to this.

Mapping store names: ``vmware_datastore`` and ``filesystem``
to ``vmware`` and ``file`` respectively to be in sync with glance_store
entry point names and at the same time accommodate backward
compatibility for old configuration files that might still be using
``filesystem`` and ``vmware_datastore``.
Note: This change applies only when multiple image locations are being
used and ``location_strategy`` configuration option is set to
``store_type``.

Note: Including glance-api.conf with this patch with the updated
configuration option help text.

Impact:
UpgradeImpact

Credit:
This patch has a release note authored by Brian Rosmaita

Change-Id: I3d8593cdae6780ae721afedcf47dd45afa684f25
Closes-Bug: #1615852
(cherry picked from commit dfa0682cac93938fc6fe3c0ccfb0640a0a18ee33)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance refs/changes/18/371618/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: mapping = {'file': ['file', 'filesystem'], 'vmware': ['vsphere']} # The following conversion of ``filesystem`` and # ``vmware_datastore`` to ``file`` and ``vmware`` respectively # are to make store names consistent in Glance and glance_store # and also be backward compatible. # Reference: Bug 1615852 if preferred_store == 'filesystem': preferred_store = 'file' if preferred_store == 'vmware_datastore': preferred_store = 'vmware'

commit_message:
Create runtime-ssh-host-keys element

Move managing of SSH host keys into a dedicated element.

Because glean doesn't generate SSH host keys anymore, we need to do it
with a systemd script. This is already handled by CentOS / Fedora so
we don't want to add it there.

This was done to address the upstream bug in debian:

  https://bugs.debian.org/cgi-bin/bugreport.cgi?bug=500192

Change-Id: I31ad667672e08350872db21a83445fe0aa7a4a39
Signed-off-by: Paul Belanger <pabelanger@redhat.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder refs/changes/66/374366/12 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #!/bin/bash if [ "${DIB_DEBUG_TRACE:-0}" -gt 0 ]; then set -x fi set -eu set -o pipefail case "$DIB_INIT_SYSTEM" in upstart) # nothing to do exit 0 ;; systemd) systemctl enable ssh-keygen.service ;; openrc) # let dib-init-system's postinstall handle enabling init scripts exit 0 ;; *) echo "Unsupported init system" exit 1 ;; esac

commit_message:
Updated OSIC project for HW specific flavors

In the OSIC we'd like to split workloads such that they're running on
hardware specific flavors. This is being done so that we can gather
metrics on our various hardware profiles. The initial commit has a
low 24 node quota however once we establish that everything works as
expected we intend to spread the quota out evenly and remove the
original cloud1-config entry.

Change-Id: I4f12c9013040a49c17e5a636dd3e0d719a2ace3e
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

commit_message:
Modify the run-playbooks script to run faster

The run playbook script was iterating through the included playbooks
from setup-everything serially. This change makes it thread until a
blocking playbook is encountered. This should improve gate run times.

This also re-orders a few items in our "setup-*" playbooks to better
support running plays in parallel.

Change-Id: Icc249d2d32647d3b4d429c0bca4f7469f1b2b7c3
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

commit_message:
Add defaults for os_workers fact

This change adds a default value of 2 to the os_workers fact for spec
tests. This fact was added to openstacklib as part of
Ia588817fde9203a134bc9eaad9a5bd5453d7639a to be used as the default for
worker configurations within the puppet openstack management. This
change lays the groundwork to have this fact defined for unit tests as
we implement the cutover from processcount to os_workers.

Change-Id: Ic7c92385b8e6b63264f21ce7a5ab957889b8b104

subject: Update wsgi-intercept to 1.4.1
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-09-27 10:08:29.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/requirements/commit/42a9e33455e6fbd585ce689dbc39b0bb2af1c6e9', 'message': "Update wsgi-intercept to 1.4.1

1.4.1 adds (optional) support for checking that response headers
sent by the intercepted application are in the proper form (`str`
objects in python 2 and python 3, thus bytes in one and not the
other). This is hard to test in the code that uses wsgi-intercept
because most HTTP libraries will normalize the response headers
to a convenient type.

This functionality will be used in in the tests of the placement
API in nova.

This patch also changes the wsgi-intercept entry in global-requirements
to use the version of the name with a '-' not an '_' so that there is
consistency between the global-requirements and upper-constraints files.

commit_message:
Update wsgi-intercept to 1.4.1

1.4.1 adds (optional) support for checking that response headers
sent by the intercepted application are in the proper form (`str`
objects in python 2 and python 3, thus bytes in one and not the
other). This is hard to test in the code that uses wsgi-intercept
because most HTTP libraries will normalize the response headers
to a convenient type.

This functionality will be used in the tests of the placement
API in nova.

Change-Id: I3b8aabda929fe39b60e645abb6fabb9769554829

commit_message:
Move rspec-puppet-facts inclusion to spec helper

This change takes the inclusion of the default facts that we currently
do in all of the puppet modules and puts it into
puppet-openstack_spec_helper/facts to reduce the amount of code
duplication across modules as it relates to  rspec-puppet-facts.

Change-Id: I03303214096ea657078b27aff6bbbd96b119ba30
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-openstack_spec_helper refs/changes/59/375159/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- features: - Added a new facts module that can be pulled in by the other puppet modules to be able to manage the inclusion of rspec-puppet-facts and the related default facts in a single inclusion. other: - Require a minimum of rspec-puppet-facts 1.7.0 due to the addition of the add_custom_fact function which was not available until this version.

commit_message:
Fix incorrect output of "nova show" for long user data

New argument "--wrap" is added for "nova show" command to wrap
the output. The default wrap length is set to 0 i.e. no wrap.
Usage: nova show --wrap 80 <server-id>

closes-bug: 1616415

Change-Id: I7f4869d743f7bf9ff653183a5767134c796c440a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-novaclient refs/changes/03/362303/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _print_server(cs, args, server=None, wrap=0): utils.print_dict(info, wrap=wrap)@utils.arg( '--wrap', dest='wrap', metavar='<integer>', default=80, help=_('Wrap the output to a specified length, or 0 to disable.')) _print_server(cs, args, wrap=int(args.wrap))

commit_message:
Default the variable if the group doesn't exist

We have situations where configuration files require host settings, but
they don't require the host_group. For example, nova requires ironic
variables but not ironic, or keystone with rabbitmq etc.

To prevent a situation where we require a host just to get the IP, or a
situation where we have to override the variable inside each role - lets
check if the group exists and set the variable accordingly.

Additionally, to prevent having to set the same long hostvar each time,
we can set that at the top of each "group" variables and then set those
variables appropriately.

Change-Id: I60d4079e913690069b5c44b83019a171dd3e4593

commit_message:
Change assertTrue(isinstance()) by optimal assert

Some of tests use different method of assertTrue(isinstance(A, B)) or
assertEqual(type(A), B). The correct way is to use assertIsInstance(A,
B) provided by testtools.

Change-Id: Id51f6385dc61a73e29ba38f738d945ef234553ab
Closes-bug: #1268480
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/40/262540/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: Fixes(backport) the length of resource field in database for quota tables
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-09-23 01:24:43.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/17b7709a1640b88ecec6eabb58ae2c5c354095d8', 'message': "Fixes(backport) the length of resource field in database for quota tables

Problem description:
Currently whenever the combination of (volume_type,property) is longer
255 characters for resource column in quota tables, the cinder
quota-update command errors. This change increases the length to 275
so that even if the length of volume_type is 256 characters, the
resource column gets some extra space and command does not error out

Challenge:
During live upgrade, then operator is supposed to migrate the DB first.
Now the problem is that in MySQL expanding VARCHAR table field
from <0;255> length to <256;+inf). It is an operation that will copy
whole table and lock it for writing during the migration.
This isn't something you want to do on a live deployment. Hence,
there can be a impact during upgrade for the same

This change is a backport into stable/newton and uses slot 80
of DB migration reservations

UpgradeImpact
Change-Id: I4ce659f79601445c7666cd505d3c852887aaa7b0
Closes-bug: #1608849

commit_message:
Fixes(backport) the length of resource field in database for quota tables

Problem description:
Currently whenever the combination of (volume_type,property) is longer
255 characters for resource column in quota tables, the cinder
quota-update command errors. This change increases the length to 275
so that even if the length of volume_type is 256 characters, the
resource column gets some extra space and command does not error out

Challenge:
During live upgrade, then operator is supposed to migrate the DB first.
Now the problem is that in MySQL expanding VARCHAR table field
from <0;255> length to <256;+inf). It is an operation that will copy
whole table and lock it for writing during the migration.
This isn't something you want to do on a live deployment. Hence,
there can be a impact during upgrade for the same

This change is a backport into stable/newton and uses slot 80
of DB migration reservations

UpgradeImpact
Change-Id: I4ce659f79601445c7666cd505d3c852887aaa7b0
Closes-bug: #1608849

commit_message:
Dell SC: Error attaching after LV-AFO

Fixed miscellaneous errors dealing with the state of Dell's
Live Volumes after a LV AFO event.

Was looking for the original volume and sc server object
after the primary was down. We now look for the new primary
and attach that.

Ensure export was failing to properly kick off a swap
back to the original primary if it was available.

Fixed an error with deleting replications.

Added a workaround to finding a ScLiveVolume object. Previous
method could return stale information.

Change-Id: I58889adbcf279d4b0107cbc51e1dace888a3fb15
Closes-Bug: #1617401
(cherry picked from commit 45bc8abc47456bae6b6b3dd7857eccbea102b5fd)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/83/375083/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Find the volume on the storage center. Note that if this # is live volume and we are swapped this will be the back # half of the live volume. scvolume = api.find_volume(volume_name, provider_id, islivevol) if scvolume: # Get the SSN it is on. ssn = scvolume['instanceId'].split('.')[0] # Find our server. scserver = api.find_server(initiator_name, ssn) # No? commit_message:
Use the DIB image id in glance uploads

In order to make use of shade's intelligence in not reuploading an image
that is already uploaded with the same hash value we need to make sure
that any reattempts at uploads use the same image name. To do this we
move away from timestamp suffixes in the glance image names and instead
use the DIB image id. This way if we try to upload the same DIB image to
a cloud more than once shade should notice and make this very very
cheap.

Change-Id: Ie6c82942ecd7d27e45e9092c137660d016d996c5

or enable_isolated_metadata configuration options to True.

commit_message:
Workaround DHCP agent gate issues

The DHCP agent logs in the gate-tempest-dsvm-networking-ovn job
see numerous key errors as reported in bug 1624079. These errors
appear to be related to setting the DHCP agent force_metadata
or enable_isolated_metadata configuration options to True.

These key errors may be related to the recent instability of the
gate-tempest-dsvm-networking-ovn job. While bug 1624079 is being
fixed, we will only force the DHCP agent to handle metadata when
native OVN L3 is enabled.

Change-Id: Iaa13240150dcf7541e4b2adfb9112cf9d006442b
Related-Bug: 1624079
(cherry picked from commit 1a765d7afd3a37f4dd6eb6362705a425a7764e6b)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/networking-ovn refs/changes/52/374852/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # layer-3 is enabled. For consistency it would be nice to always force # conventional DHCP agent to provide metadata for all networks regardless # of the layer-3 support. However, this cannot be done until bug/1624079 # is fixed. if [[ "$OVN_L3_MODE" == "True" ]]; then iniset $Q_DHCP_CONF_FILE DEFAULT force_metadata True fi
deleted_lines: # layer-3 is enabled. So for consistency, regardless of the layer-3 # support, the conventional DHCP agent will be forced to provide # metadata for all networks. iniset $Q_DHCP_CONF_FILE DEFAULT force_metadata True

Use centralised test scripts

This patch consumes the test scripts implemented by
https://review.openstack.org/375061 to ensure that
the tests and test preparation is consistent and
more maintainable.

Change-Id: Ib7d3bff4c80a34508d701a940fa9b8f88f33678f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_cloudkitty refs/changes/38/377938/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ROLE_NAME=galera_server VIRTUAL_ENV={envdir} WORKING_DIR={toxinidir}[testenv:tests_clone] commands = bash -c "if [ ! -d "{toxinidir}/tests/common" ]; then \ git clone https://git.openstack.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-tests {toxinidir}/tests/common; \ fi" {[testenv:tests_clone]commands} bash -c "{toxinidir}/tests/common/test-pep8.sh" {[testenv:tests_clone]commands} bash -c "{toxinidir}/tests/common/test-bashate.sh" -rhttp://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/openstack-ansible-tests/plain/test-ansible-deps.txt {[testenv:tests_clone]commands} bash -c "{toxinidir}/tests/common/test-ansible-env-prep.sh" bash -c "{toxinidir}/tests/common/test-log-collect.sh"
deleted_lines: git rm wget VIRTUAL_ENV={envdir} # Run hacking/flake8 check for all python files bash -c "grep --recursive --binary-files=without-match \ --files-with-match '^.!.*python$' \ --exclude-dir .eggs \ --exclude-dir .git \ --exclude-dir .tox \ --exclude-dir *.egg-info \ --exclude-dir doc \ {toxinidir} | xargs flake8 --verbose" # Run bashate check for all bash scripts # Ignores the following rules: # E003: Indent not multiple of 4 (we prefer to use multiples of 2) # E006: Line longer than 79 columns (as many scripts use jinja # templating, this is very difficult) # E040: Syntax error determined using `bash -n` (as many scripts # use jinja templating, this will often fail and the syntax # error will be discovered in execution anyway) bash -c "grep --recursive --binary-files=without-match \ --files-with-match '^.!.*\(ba\)\?sh$' \ --exclude-dir .tox \ --exclude-dir .git \ {toxinidir} | xargs bashate --error . --verbose --ignore=E003,E006,E040" ansible==2.1.1 ansible-lint>=2.7.0,<3.0.0 setenv = {[testenv]setenv} ANSIBLE_HOST_KEY_CHECKING = False ANSIBLE_SSH_CONTROL_PATH = /tmp/%%h-%%r # TODO (odyssey4me) These are only here as they are non-standard folder # names for Ansible 1.9.x. ANSIBLE_ACTION_PLUGINS = {homedir}/.ansible/plugins/action ANSIBLE_CALLBACK_PLUGINS = {homedir}/.ansible/plugins/callback ANSIBLE_FILTER_PLUGINS = {homedir}/.ansible/plugins/filter ANSIBLE_LOOKUP_PLUGINS = {homedir}/.ansible/plugins/lookup # This is required as the default is the current path or a path specified # in ansible.cfg ANSIBLE_LIBRARY = {homedir}/.ansible/plugins/library # This is required as the default is '/etc/ansible/roles' or a path # specified in ansible.cfg ANSIBLE_ROLES_PATH = {homedir}/.ansible/roles:{toxinidir}/.. ANSIBLE_TRANSPORT = "ssh" rm -rf {homedir}/.ansible/plugins git clone https://git.openstack.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-plugins \ {homedir}/.ansible/plugins rm -rf {homedir}/.ansible/roles ansible-galaxy install \ --role-file={toxinidir}/tests/ansible-role-requirements.yml \ --force rm -rf {homedir}/.ansible/roles/os_cloudkitty bash -c "ln -s {toxinidir} {homedir}/.ansible/roles/os_cloudkitty" rm -rf {toxinidir}/tests/playbooks git clone https://git.openstack.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-tests \ {toxinidir}/tests/playbookssetenv = {[testenv:ansible]setenv} bash -c 'mkdir -p {toxinidir}/logs' bash -c 'rsync --archive --verbose --ignore-errors /var/log/ /openstack/log/ {toxinidir}/logs/ || true' bash -c 'find "{toxinidir}/logs/" -type f | sed "p;s|$|.txt|" | xargs -n2 mv' bash -c 'command gzip --best --recursive "{toxinidir}/logs/"'setenv = {[testenv:ansible]setenv}setenv = {[testenv:ansible]setenv}

subject: Fix subunit-trace output with tempest run
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-09-20 12:34:27.000000000', 'files': ['tempest/cmd/run.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tempest/commit/18d2d6796b4f83d42718f7682dcdf06780187b33', 'message': "Fix subunit-trace output with tempest run

Now that we're using tempest run in tox it became clear that the
subunit-trace arguments we were using in tempest run did not match what
we were previously using in pretty_tox.sh. This makes debugging failures
slightly more difficult than before because the failures aren't printed
at the end of the run. This commit adds the necessary flags to tempest
run calling of subunit-trace to have the same behavior as before.

Change-Id: Ib066acca792d4f357763235ef4593062e9978f0b
"}]
commit_message:
Fix subunit-trace output with tempest run

Now that we're using tempest run in tox it became clear that the
subunit-trace arguments we were using in tempest run did not match what
we were previously using in pretty_tox.sh. This makes debugging failures
slightly more difficult than before because the failures aren't printed
at the end of the run. This commit adds the necessary flags to tempest
run calling of subunit-trace to have the same behavior as before.

Change-Id: Ib066acca792d4f357763235ef4593062e9978f0b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/49/373249/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: returncodes['subunit-trace'] = subunit_trace.trace( subunit_r, sys.stdout, post_fails=True, print_failures=True)

commit_message:
Allow haproxy to bind to any port in CentOS

This patch allows haproxy to bind to any port without SELinux denying
the access. Although this isn't ideal, we can load up some custom
SELinux policy later and turn this boolean off.

Closes-bug: 1628266
Change-Id: I3cdbf25c90b2c06d9698e1cd9679d04e5690e367
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-haproxy_server refs/changes/08/378008/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - name: Prevent SELinux from preventing haproxy from binding to arbitrary ports seboolean: name: haproxy_connect_any state: yes persistent: yes tags: - haproxy-service-config notify: - Restart haproxy when: - ansible_pkg_mgr == 'yum'

to ``vmware`` and ``file`` respectively to be in sync with glance_store
names and at the same time accommodate backoward compatibility for old
conf files using ``filesystem`` and ``vmware_datastore``.

Change-Id: I3d8593cdae6780ae721afedcf47dd45afa684f25
closes-bug:1615852

The store names used in Glance and glance_store are not in sync with
each other.
This can confuse operators who have to use different names to refer to
the same store while setting values for configuration options such as
``store_type_preference`` in glance and configuration option like ``store`` in
glance_store. This inconsistency may also confuse for developers during
code changes, complicating  future code changes with respect to this.

Converting store names: ``vmware_datastore`` and ``filesystem``
to ``vmware`` and ``file`` respectively to be in sync with glance_store
names and at the same time accommodate backoward compatibility for old
conf files that might still be using ``filesystem`` and ``vmware_datastore``.

commit_message:
Fixing inconsistency in Glance store names.

The store names used in glance and glance_store are not in sync with
each other.

This can confuse operators who have to use different names to refer to
the same store while setting values for configuration options such as
``store_type_preference`` in glance and configuration option like
``store`` in glance_store. This inconsistency may also confuse
developers during code changes, complicating future code changes with
respect to this.

Mapping store names: ``vmware_datastore`` and ``filesystem``
to ``vmware`` and ``file`` respectively to be in sync with glance_store
entry point names and at the same time accommodate backward
compatibility for old configuration files that might still be using
``filesystem`` and ``vmware_datastore``.
Note: This change applies only when multiple image locations are being
used and ``location_strategy`` configuration option is set to
``store_type``.

Note: This change does not require a config refresh change.

Impact:
UpgradeImpact

Credit:
This patch has a release note authored by Brian Rosmaita

Change-Id: I3d8593cdae6780ae721afedcf47dd45afa684f25
Closes-Bug: #1615852
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance refs/changes/02/359402/9 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if preferred_store == 'filesystem': preferred_store = 'file' if preferred_store == 'vmware_datastore': preferred_store = 'vmware' if store == 'filesystem' or store == 'vmware_datastore': continue

commit_message:
Add eavesdrop logging for #openstack-election

Since IRC channel #openstack-election is now an official contact
point[1] for concerns related to OpenStack elections, the channel should
be properly logged.  See also [2].

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2016-September/102818.html
[2] https://review.openstack.org/368879

Change-Id: I159ad6df41e62f6764c237f63532c2d27e4da2bc

Add Apache 2.0 license to source file

As per OpenStack licensing guide lines [1]:
[H102 H103] Newly contributed Source Code should be licensed under
the Apache 2.0 license.

[1] http://docs.openstack.org/developer/hacking/#openstack-licensing

commit_message:
Write down OpenStack principles

Beyond the Four Opens, the OpenStack community (and the Technical
Committee as its direct representation) operates on a lot of
unwritten principles, which were transmitted by oral tradition
by the elders and appear from time to time as a snippet of wisdom
in the middle of a TC meeting.

It is more than time for us to document those principles, to make
them clearer to everyone and harder to ignore. To give credit where
due, the bulk of this document was written by Monty Taylor, with
input from a number of other folks including (but not limited to)
the list of co-authors below.

Change-Id: I0134b0aa9b512ee61fbb908d23e7260ff2491bba
Co-Authored-By: Monty Taylor <mordred@inaugust.com>
Co-Authored-By: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>
Co-Authored-By: John Garbutt <john@johngarbutt.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/governance refs/changes/60/357260/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ================== Guiding Principles ================== OpenStack has a set of guiding principles that are used to inform and shape decisions. These are not aspirational. Rather, they form the bedrock upon which the OpenStack community and software are built. First and foremost, OpenStack follows :doc:`reference/opens`. All four of them are essential, and most of the principles described in this document derive from them. One OpenStack ------------- OpenStack is one project with a common mission. The organization into separate source code repositories and teams allows contributors to focus on their areas of interest and expertise, but does not make OpenStack a loose confederation of independent projects. OpenStack First, Project Team Second, Company Third --------------------------------------------------- OpenStack leaders are expected to put the needs of OpenStack first in their decision making, before the needs of any individual project team. They are also expected to put the needs of their project team before the needs of the organization they work for, if any. All three needs are essential to OpenStack's health, but the broad OpenStack needs are the hardest and have the least direct representation. People who need to be a strong voice for their project team or their company are highly valued, but should strongly consider whether it is appropriate for them to put those needs to the side at times before seeking or accepting a leadership role in OpenStack. Democracy --------- While we strive to build community consensus around decisions, all decisions are finally made or delegated by people who have been democratically elected. One Contributor, One Vote ------------------------- The voice of the contributor community is essential, and forms the basis of our democracy. A person with a thousand patches in an OpenStack release should not have a voice as thousand times as strong. Contribution does not mean only writing patches, although patches included in a release is the most straight-forward measure of contribution to track. Efforts at limiting the electorate to quantifiable contribution, no matter the form, are intended only to prevent gaming of the system, not as a value judgement on relative worth of the various different forms of community contributions. Changes in Leadership are Good ------------------------------ Long term strength of OpenStack rests in democratically elected leaders who change over time to remain representative of the body of contributors. OpenStack does not have and does not want any sort of dictator, benevolent or otherwise. Leaders in OpenStack should not consider their role 'for life', should cultivate the next generation of leaders, and should step down considerately. OpenStack is Built for our Users -------------------------------- OpenStack is ultimately built to be used. We need to factor the needs of our existing and future users when making decisions. Empowering Business ------------------- From the beginning OpenStack has striven to make businesses who build products on or with OpenStack successful. Level Playing Field ------------------- OpenStack should not empower one business over another, or else the project is not truly a place where everyone can collaborate. While the needs of the constituent businesses are essential, they must be balanced with each other lest OpenStack decisions unwittingly be made by unelected people behind closed doors. OpenStack Primarily Produces Software ------------------------------------- While the software that OpenStack produces has well defined and documented APIs, the primary output of OpenStack is software. The technical community expects people who run OpenStack to run the software produced by and in the community. We all should Always Follow the OpenStack Way --------------------------------------------- No one is outside of the rules. We derive considerable value from the empowerment that everyone in the community enjoys from equal application of rules. When parts of OpenStack exist outside of the rules, everyone suffers. While it can be tempting to circumvent process for expedience, doing so is not scalable from a community perspective. It leads to the subversion of democracy and an abdication of our principles of Open Design and Open Community. Code drops and decisions pre-made outside of OpenStack governance are rejected because they by defintion did not include the community. Participation is Voluntary -------------------------- The leadership of OpenStack should not need to find itself in a position of enforcing the rules because existing under their aegis is a choice in the first place. There are plenty of Open Source projects in the world, there are plenty of organizations under which projects can collaborate, and there are plenty of cloud related projects that are both Open and Closed. If the OpenStack Principles are in conflict with someone's thoughts or dreams, it is probably best to find something else to do that is more aligned with those.

This change includes:

 - volume actions
 - volume types
 - snapshots

commit_message:
WIP major-upgrade-pacemaker cleanup and fixes

WIP because I plan to split this commit out in multiple bugs and
reviews. Right now I need it as a placeholder to add all the fixes
to get my upgrades to work.

In this commit we fix the following:
1. Use is_bootstrap_node everywhere to make the code more consistent
2. We disable/enable in openstack-cinder-volume _1.sh and _2.sh
   otherwise when the cluster starts openstack-cinder-volume will start
   before galera (it was disabled previously) but cinder db-manage will
   not have run yet so we will get a bunch of sql errors. This is not
   fatal but it is good to have.
3. We now explicitely disable/stop and then remove the resources that
   are moving to systemd. We do this because we want to make sure they
   are all stopped before doing a yum upgrade, which otherwise would
   take ages due to rabbitmq and galera being down.
4. We need mongod which is now a systemd service up and running before
   calling ceilometer-dbsync. There is still a race here: mongod might not
   be up on all nodes so ceilometer-dbsync will fail a couple of times
   before that. As it retries indefinitely we should be good.
5. We actually need to start the systemd services in
   major_upgrade_controller_pacemaker_2.sh and not stop them
6. Nova upgrades need to set host_scheduler and filter_scheduler as in
   Newton the previous used values are deprecated

Change-Id: I6f22db8a406924a03e2ad96deaf5a56d6da94578
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/27/375827/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # 3. Take the cluster out of maintenance-mode and do a resource cleanup # 4. Remove all the resources that won't be managed by pacemaker in newton. The outcome will be # that they are stopped and removed from pacemakers control # 5. Do a resource cleanup to make sure the cluster is in a clean state # At this stage all the pacemaker resources are removed from the CIB. Once we remove the # maintenance-mode those systemd resources will keep on running. They shall be systemd enabled # via the puppet converge step later on pcs property set maintenance-mode=false # which we want to keep. We now disable and then delete each resource # that will move to systemd. # We want the systemd resources be stopped before doing "yum update", # that way "systemctl try-restart <service>" is no-op because the # service was down already if ! pcs resource disable "$resource" --wait=600; then echo_error "ERROR: resource $resource failed to be disabled" exit 1 fi
deleted_lines: # 3. Remove all the resources that won't be managed by pacemaker in newton. Note that they # will show up as ORPHANED but they will keep running normally via systemd. They will be # enabled to start at boot by puppet during the converge step # 4. Take the cluster out of maintenance-mode and do a resource cleanup # which we want to keep. We now delete each resource that will move to systemd # Note that the corresponding systemd resource will stay running, which means that # later when we do the "yum update", things will be a bit slower because each # "systemctl try-restart <service>" is not a no-op any longer because the service is up # and running and it will be restarted with rabbitmq being down. # We need to add --force because the cluster is in maintenance mode and the resource # is unmanaged. The if serves to make this idempotent # At this stage all the pacemaker resources are removed from the CIB. Once we remove the # maintenance-mode those systemd resources will keep on running. They shall be systemd enabled # via the puppet converge step later on pcs property set maintenance-mode=false

commit_message:
Fix request_spec conversion from o.vo to dict

Turns out I7dae83667a1aca92c552fbfaa1e90c6558e293bf had a mistake and
was unconditionally converting RequestSpec o.vo to dictionary just
before sending it to the scheduler. This wasn't noticed as scheduler
manager has compatibility shim in place that converts the dictionary
back into o.vo when it's received.

The problem this produces is that we cannot drop the compatibility
shim from manager until 4.0 scheduler RPC API. This commit fixes that.

Change-Id: I7beaaddcff079dfe7a0032e2cf2afa75a5e88522
Closes-Bug: 1625170
(cherry picked from commit 32bfddf841ec2b15f022af2bb0e7666af0bc4777)

subject: Correct fix for IPv6 auto address interfaces
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-09-27 11:49:01.000000000', 'files': ['neutron/common/ipv6_utils.py', 'neutron/tests/unit/agent/linux/test_dhcp.py', 'neutron/agent/linux/dhcp.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/c0d0986e8b7412f7c37db799177dc529ce9045d2', 'message': "Correct fix for IPv6 auto address interfaces

This is a partial revert of d1fb4238306f854ab610204a50c5cdc20ea5c770.
That patch attempted to allow the DHCP agent to manage IPv6 interfaces
to avoid a KeyError in the subnet_interface_map. However, this led
to races with router advertisements and static configuration
(see bug 1627902).

The correct fix was actually a very simple conditional that was broken
because this map shouldn't have been referenced for IPv6 subnets in
the first place. The force metadata option was shortcutting the whole
evaluation so the agent was trying to add a metadata route to a v6
subnet.

This patch undoes the v6 changes from
d1fb4238306f854ab610204a50c5cdc20ea5c770, corrects the conditional,
and adds a simple unit test that ensures the branch doesn't throw
and error.

Closes-Bug: #1624079
Change-Id: Ide494b6333a4f1e279ab58aa27c0aa719e79545d
"}]
commit_message:
Correct fix for IPv6 auto address interfaces

This is a partial revert of d1fb4238306f854ab610204a50c5cdc20ea5c770.
That patch attempted to allow the DHCP agent to manage IPv6 interfaces
to avoid a KeyError in the subnet_interface_map. However, this led
to races with router advertisements and static configuration
(see bug 1627902).

The correct fix was actually a very simple conditional that was broken
because this map shouldn't have been referenced for IPv6 subnets in
the first place. The force metadata option was shortcutting the whole
evaluation so the agent was trying to add a metadata route to a v6
subnet.

This patch undoes the v6 changes from
d1fb4238306f854ab610204a50c5cdc20ea5c770, corrects the conditional,
and adds a simple unit test that ensures the branch doesn't throw
and error.

Closes-Bug: #1624079
Change-Id: Ide494b6333a4f1e279ab58aa27c0aa719e79545d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/26/377626/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: if (self.conf.force_metadata or (isolated_subnets[subnet.id] and self.conf.enable_isolated_metadata and subnet.ip_version == 4)): if not ipv6_utils.is_slaac_subnet(subnet):

subject: Tag neutron-lib as tc-approved-release
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-09-16 19:33:11.000000000', 'files': ['reference/projects.yaml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/governance/commit/0f90eed0c9fca506950aab3399139a63645fbfee', 'message': "Tag neutron-lib as tc-approved-release

Neutron-lib was created in late 2015 by the Neutron team with the intent
of splitting out stable, reusable library code from the main Neutron
repository. [1]

As such, neutron-lib is an important piece of under-the-hood machinery
for how Neutron functions going forward.  Some or all of it may be a
reasonable candidate for inclusion in future DefCore Interoperability
Guidelines as a Designated Section.  Although as a library project it
does not expose any Capabilities to end users of OpenStack clouds
directly via an API, it does provide code that is or may in the future
be invoked by Capabilities that are required by Interoperability
Guidelines.

At present, the DefCore Committee would be unable to consider adding
part or all of neutron-lib as a Designated Section to future Guidelines
because it isn't designated as part of the TC-approved release. [2]
This means (as an extreme example) that a vendor could entirely replace
neutron-lib with it's own independently created code and still have the
resulting product bear the OpenStack trademark.  By tagging neutron-lib
as tc-approved-release, the DefCore Committee would be allowed to
consider adding Designated Sections to future Guidelines that include
neutron-lib, thereby making the community developed code required.

[1]
http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/neutron-specs/specs/liberty/neutron-lib.html
[2]
http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/defcore/tree/doc/source/process/2016A.rst#n86

Change-Id: I6befe442c31b812f3d3b17b21ac844be96a419b2
"}]
commit_message:
Tag neutron-lib as tc-approved-release

Neutron-lib was created in late 2015 by the Neutron team with the intent
of splitting out stable, reusable library code from the main Neutron
repository. [1]

As such, neutron-lib is an important piece of under-the-hood machinery
for how Neutron functions going forward.  Some or all of it may be a
reasonable candidate for inclusion in future DefCore Interoperability
Guidelines as a Designated Section.  Although as a library project it
does not expose any Capabilities to end users of OpenStack clouds
directly via an API, it does provide code that is or may in the future
be invoked by Capabilities that are required by Interoperability
Guidelines.

At present, the DefCore Committee would be unable to consider adding
part or all of neutron-lib as a Designated Section to future Guidelines
because it isn't designated as part of the TC-approved release. [2]
This means (as an extreme example) that a vendor could entirely replace
neutron-lib with it's own independently created code and still have the
resulting product bear the OpenStack trademark.  By tagging neutron-lib
as tc-approved-release, the DefCore Committee would be allowed to
consider adding Designated Sections to future Guidelines that include
neutron-lib, thereby making the community developed code required.

[1]
http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/neutron-specs/specs/liberty/neutron-lib.html
[2]
http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/defcore/tree/doc/source/process/2016A.rst#n86

Change-Id: I6befe442c31b812f3d3b17b21ac844be96a419b2

commit_message:
Wait for floating_ip to detach from server after deletion

test_minimum_basic_scenario expects floating_ip detaching
from server immediately after deletion, and this may not
be true in production clouds(we watched in our system that
it took about 5 seconds for the floating_ip to disappear
from server's address). So this is to add wait after
floating_ip deletion.

Change-Id: Iedc6197829f2cb388878fdb8e257489482a41d93

commit_message:
Remove OpenStack-Salt from governance

OpenStack Salt project has missed several deadlines for various
reasons and was probably way too early for them to be in the
Big Tent. Several contributors to the project were in a startup
that recently got acquired as well. When they figure out their
next steps and understand what it means to be under the "Big Tent"
they are welcome to re-propose adding them back.

Change-Id: I6e55b7404a53c8326c3a3eed065bd6c91db0e1ec

revisions:

removing the Astara from TC governance. Most of the projects's core team has
moved to different roles and there is not a ready set of maintainers available
to replace them and continue the project in its current form.  Retiring the
project will enable interested members of the community to reorganize
and restructure and if desired reapply for goverance in the future.

The Newton release will be the last release by the current team and will
provide time for any deployments to migrate to another solution.

Change-Id: Ic8e0e3115a379bdc876f6a064519b233515bcd3a
"}]
commit_message:
Remove Astara from governance

The Astara team believes the community's best interest are served by
removing the Astara from TC governance. Most of the projects's core team has
moved to different roles and there is not a ready set of maintainers available
to replace them and continue the project in its current form.  Retiring the
project will enable interested members of the community to reorganize
and restructure and if desired reapply for goverance in the future.

The Newton release will be the last release by the current team and will
provide time for any deployments to migrate to another solution.

Change-Id: Ic8e0e3115a379bdc876f6a064519b233515bcd3a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/governance refs/changes/09/376609/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Handle keystoneauth exceptions in retry logic

The retry_logic in do_request catches neutronclient errors, but if a
SessionClient is being used, nothing throws neutronclient errors -
instead keystoneauth Session throws keystoneauth exceptions.

Add the keystoneauth.exceptions.ConnectionError to the things that
handle the error and retry.

Change-Id: If16e50ee53279652fbdfc2d13d5509f46a54124a

subject: Enhance 'redstack clean' regarding modules
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-09-01 20:13:46.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/trove-integration/commit/cf132cd0ddd9b59686bddec71416eb84aeffec98', 'message': "Enhance 'redstack clean' regarding modules

Adds a sql command to make sure the modules are not marked
as having been applied to an instance so that they can be
deleted (otherwise an error may occur if the instance hasn't
gone away yet).

Also enhanced the logic to only sleep if objects are found
and to keep trying until the objects are gone (up to 10 times).
This makes runs with nothing to delete faster and negates having
to run the script multiple times if objects delete slower than
expected.

commit_message:
Enhance 'redstack clean' regarding modules

Adds a sql command to make sure the modules are not marked
as having been applied to an instance so that they can be
deleted (otherwise an error may occur if the instance hasn't
gone away yet).

Enhanced the logic to only sleep if objects are found
and to keep trying until the objects are gone (up to 10 times).
This makes runs with nothing to delete faster and negates having
to run the script multiple times if objects delete slower than
expected.

Added a check for server-groups to delete them if they exist.

Fixed security group delete to look for the 'default' name instead
of an id of '1' (which could be incorrect).  Also switched it to
use the OpenStack client, since Nova was reporting a deprecation
warning:

  WARNING: Command secgroup-delete is deprecated and will be removed
           after Nova 15.0.0 is released. Use python-neutronclient or
           python-openstackclient instead.

Unfortunately python-openstackclient has a warning of its own:

  WARNING: openstackclient.common.utils is deprecated and will be
           removed after Jun 2017. Please use osc_lib.utils

Hopefully this warning will go away once the 'openstack' client is
updated.

Change-Id: If429b2d04111a6e8adbb90c001002215a927d1da

subject: WIP: Implement base retryutils
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-05-26 21:49:27.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo.utils/commit/1dfb47497b654b982be4552bf40fc90c7fcd045e', 'message': "WIP: Implement base retryutils

Based on a ML discussion we had awhile back [1], we decided it
was worth looking into some common 'retry' utils, both from a
generic perspective, as well as from an RPC client perspective.

In the ML we decided to reuse python 'retrying' as much as possible.
However,  we need additional functionality [2] to support a 'stepping'
scheme. While it might be nice to add this directly to retrying, a quick
look on github shows no activity in awhile for this repo, including pull
requests  months old without any response from the author.

Therefore this patch proposes an approach for wrapping the retrying
impl allowing us to dynamically add new wait/stop behavior. Decorators
are provided to register new wait/stop functions as well as an initial
impl of the 'stepping' wait (as per [2]).

NB: This patch is a work in progress. I'd like feedback on this approach
before I spend cycles implementing the UTs.

[1] http://goo.gl/k2IH8F
[2] http://goo.gl/cSC4D8

commit_message:
WIP: Implement base retryutils

Based on a ML discussion we had awhile back [1], we decided it
was worth looking into some common 'retry' utils, both from a
generic perspective, as well as from an RPC client perspective.

In the ML we decided to reuse python 'retrying' as much as possible.
However,  we need additional functionality [2] to support a 'stepping'
scheme. While it might be nice to add this directly in the retrying
repo, the maintainer of this repo is unresponsive. Multiple PR
attempts have gone unnoticed and the author has not responded to
email in nearly 2 months.

With that in mind I don't see how our approach of implementing this
in the retrying repo is feasible. There are main approachs that
come to mind:
- Implement a wrapper to retrying; similar to whats done herein.
- Replace our usage of retrying with something else. Perhaps a
clone of retrying or a rewrite. NB: I'm happy to do this and
maintain.

[1] http://goo.gl/k2IH8F
[2] http://goo.gl/cSC4D8

Change-Id: I3bfe88f904e0ce5276f61df343d306d3eebd0089
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.utils refs/changes/67/321867/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import collections import retrying import six from functools import partial from oslo_utils._i18n import _ DEFAULT_WAIT_MS = 1000 class _Retrying(retrying.Retrying): """Wraps retrying.Retrying to collect and proxy custom wait/stop functions. This class provides a bridge between oslo and retrying.Retrying allowing consumers to register custom stop and wait functions to be used in retry decorators. Since the retrying implementation expects stop and wait functions to exist on self, this class must dynamically add custom methods to itself that were registered with a decorator. Consumers should not use this class directly and instead use the decorators defined in this module. """ _WAIT_FUNCS = {} _WAIT_KWARGS = {} _STOP_FUNCS = {} _STOP_KWARGS = {} _BASE_RETRYING = retrying.Retrying() def __init__(self, timeout_log_fn=None, *args, **kwargs): for wait_fn, stop_fn in map(None, _Retrying._WAIT_FUNCS.values(), _Retrying._STOP_FUNCS.values()): if wait_fn: setattr(self, wait_fn.__name__, partial(wait_fn, self)) if stop_fn: setattr(self, stop_fn.__name__, partial(stop_fn, self)) for key, val in kwargs.items(): kwarg_map = None if key in _Retrying._WAIT_KWARGS: kwarg_map = _Retrying._WAIT_KWARGS elif key in _Retrying._STOP_KWARGS: kwarg_map = _Retrying._STOP_KWARGS if kwarg_map: setattr(self, key, kwargs.pop(key) or kwarg_map.get(key)) super(_Retrying, self).__init__(*args, **kwargs) self._wait_logger = timeout_log_fn self._enable_logged_wait() def _enable_logged_wait(self): if not getattr(self, '_call_wait', None): self._call_wait = self.wait def _log_wait(attempt_number, delay_since_first_attempt_ms): sleep_time = self._call_wait(attempt_number, delay_since_first_attempt_ms) if self._wait_logger: self._wait_logger(sleep_time, attempt_number, delay_since_first_attempt_ms) return sleep_time self.wait = _log_wait @staticmethod def _add_func(func, func_map, kwarg_map, **kwargs): if func.__name__ in func_map: raise KeyError(_("Retry function '%s' " "already defined."), func.__name__) existing_kwargs = [k for k in kwargs.keys() if k in kwarg_map] if existing_kwargs: raise KeyError(_("Keyword arguments already " "registered: %s"), existing_kwargs) if hasattr(_Retrying._BASE_RETRYING, func.__name__): raise AttributeError(_("Retrying already defines: %s"), func.__name__) func_map[func.__name__] = func kwarg_map.update(kwargs) @staticmethod def add_wait_func(func, **kwargs): _Retrying._add_func(func, _Retrying._WAIT_FUNCS, _Retrying._WAIT_KWARGS, **kwargs) @staticmethod def add_stop_func(func, **kwargs): _Retrying._add_func(func, _Retrying._STOP_FUNCS, _Retrying._STOP_KWARGS, **kwargs) def _register_retry_func(register_method, *dargs, **required_kwargs): def retry_wrap(f): register_method(f, **required_kwargs) @six.wraps(f) def retry_fn(*args, **kwargs): f(*args, **kwargs) return retry_fn return (retry_wrap(dargs[0]) if len(dargs) == 1 and callable(dargs[0]) else retry_wrap) def retry_wait_func(*args, **required_kwargs): """Decorator to register a new retry wait function. This function decorates custom retrying wait functions to register them gobally for use within the retry() decorator. Once defined a custom wait function can be used by specifying it's name for the 'wait' keyword argument in the retry() decorator. As stop and wait retrying functions are defined globally, care must be taken to define unique function names and required_kwargs. Consumer's wait functions must take 3 arguments: retry_inst: A reference to the Retrying instance that will contain an attribute for each required_kwargs. previous_attempt_number: The previous attempt number. delay_since_first_attempt_ms: The delay since the first attempt in ms. For example: # define and register the wait function @retry_wait_func(foo_kwarg=my_default) def my_wait_foo(retry_inst, previous_attempt_number, delay_since_first_attempt_ms): return get_foo_wait(retry_inst.foo_kwarg, previous_attempt_number) # use retry with my_wait_foo to determine wait time @retry(wait='my_wait_foo', foo_kwarg=123, stop_max_attempt_number=11) def retry_until_foo(): # retry wait on my_wait_foo return foo() :param args: Arguments passed to the decorator. Can be used with or without invocation (e.g. @retry_wait_func or @retry_wait_func()). :param required_kwargs: An optional set of kwargs required by the function and their default values. Consumers can access their kwargs as attributes of the retry_inst. :return: The wrapped function that's now """ return _register_retry_func(_Retrying.add_wait_func, *args, **required_kwargs) def retry_stop_func(*args, **required_kwargs): """Decorator to register a new retry stop function. This function decorates custom retrying stop functions to register them gobally for use within the retry() decorator. Once defined a custom stop function can be used by specifying it's name for the 'stop' keyword argument in the retry() decorator. As stop and wait retrying functions are defined globally, care must be taken to define unique function names and required_kwargs. Consumer's stop functions must take 3 arguments: retry_inst: A reference to the Retrying instance that will contain an attribute for each required_kwargs. previous_attempt_number: The previous attempt number. delay_since_first_attempt_ms: The delay since the first attempt in ms. For example: # define the my_stop_foo custom stop function @retry_stop_func(foo_kwarg=my_default) def my_stop_foo(retry_inst, previous_attempt_number, delay_since_first_attempt_ms): return should_foo_stop(retry_inst.foo_kwarg, previous_attempt_number) # retry using my_stop_foo as the stop function @retry(stop='my_stop_foo', foo_kwarg=123, stop_max_attempt_number=11) def retry_until_foo(): # retry stop on my_wait_foo return foo() :param args: Arguments passed to the decorator. Can be used with or without invocation (e.g. @retry_stop_func or @retry_stop_func()). :param required_kwargs: An optional set of kwargs required by the function and their default values. Consumers can access their kwargs as attributes of the retry_inst. :return: The wrapped function that's now """ return _register_retry_func(_Retrying.add_stop_func, *args, **required_kwargs) def retry(*dargs, **dkwargs): """Decorate a function/method for retry behavior when invoked. This decorator behaves exactly like that of the retrying package. However it allows consumers to register and use custom stop and wait functions in conjunction with the default behavior of retrying. For more details on invocation see: https://github.com/rholder/retrying """ def wrap(f): @six.wraps(f) def wrapped_f(*args, **kwargs): return _Retrying(*dargs, **dkwargs).call(f, *args, **kwargs) return wrapped_f return (wrap(dargs[0]) if len(dargs) == 1 and callable(dargs[0]) else wrap) AttemptWaitMarker = collections.namedtuple('AttemptWaitMarker', 'attempt, wait') class AttemptWaitMarkers(object): """A mutable set of AttemptWaitMarkers. This class allows consumers to build sets of AttemptWaitMarker instances that can then be used for the plateaued_wait retry. All markers added to a instance of this class are validated to ensure there are no duplicates and valid attempt values are used. """ def __init__(self, default_wait=DEFAULT_WAIT_MS, markers=[]): self._attempts = [] self._markers = {} self._default_wait = default_wait for marker in markers: self.add(marker[0], marker[1]) @property def default_wait(self): return self._default_wait def add(self, at_attempt, wait_ms): """Add an attempt marker with given values. :param at_attempt: The attempt number to start using the wait. :param wait_ms: The wait in ms to take effect at the specified at_attempt. :return: None """ if at_attempt in self._attempts: raise IndexError("Marker for attempt '%s' already exists." % at_attempt) if at_attempt < 2: raise IndexError("Marker attempt must be greater than 1, " "but is: %s" % at_attempt) self._attempts.append(at_attempt) self._markers[str(at_attempt)] = AttemptWaitMarker(at_attempt, wait_ms) self._attempts.sort() def wait_time(self, attempt): """Retrieve the wait time for the given attempt. :param attempt: The attempt number to get wait time for. :return: The wait as specified by the set of markers for this instance. A marker is in effect (its wait value is used) if its attempt value is hit and remains in effect until the next marker is hit. If no markers are in effect yet, the default_wait for this instance is used. """ last_marker = None for attempt_marker in self._attempts: if attempt < attempt_marker: break last_marker = self._markers[str(attempt_marker)] return (last_marker.wait if last_marker else self.default_wait) @retry_wait_func(markers=None) def plateaued_wait(retry_inst, previous_attempt_number, delay_since_first_attempt_ms): """Registers a wait function for retry named 'plateaued_wait'. A plateaued wait is driven by the 'markers' kwarg who's value is a AttemptWaitMarkers instance that specifies the markers to use for wait times. Example usage: # wait 100ms until the 5th attempt # wait 300ms from the 5th to the 10th attempt # wait 400ms for any attempts after 10 # stop retrying after 20 attempts @retry(wait='plateaued_wait', markers=AttemptWaitMarkers([(1, 100), (5, 300), (10, 400)]), stop_max_attempt_number=20) def try_with_plateaued_wait(): # retried with plateaued_wait retry behavior do_something() """ return retry_inst.markers.wait_time(previous_attempt_number + 1)

commit_message:
Fix Launch Instance without Cinder

A previous patch altered the defaults in the angular Launch Instance,
but didn't account for those running without Cinder. This patch fixes
those assumptions.

Co-Authored-By: Rob Cresswell <robert.cresswell@outlook.com>
Change-Id: I8dc54fa40fa7eb8ae95a13741405f2a80337b33d
Closes-Bug: 1585761
(cherry picked from commit 723e547e848f580bf5f16899cd2bffa23c77c763)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/39/376039/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Related Options

Allows for a list of related options that may be of
interest once option is modified.  This will list
out the related options in generated sample config
files.

Implements: blueprint related-options

Change-Id: I2beedb8d2b046aff0b0a9cd5210c277ce1c6adbc
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.config refs/changes/65/304365/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if opt.related_options: related_text = ', '.join(opt.related_options) lines.append('# Related Options: %s\n' % related_text)

commit_message:
Add options to configure yaql settings

Change-Id: Id41001d74ce1008dbb5a98b962d5c53dbf39c903
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-heat refs/changes/80/377780/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: :yaql_limit_iterators => 400, :yaql_memory_quota => 20000, it 'configures yaql_limit_iterators' do is_expected.to contain_heat_config('yaql/limit_iterators').with_value( params[:yaql_limit_iterators] ) end it 'configures yaql_memory_quota' do is_expected.to contain_heat_config('yaql/memory_quota').with_value( params[:yaql_memory_quota] ) end

subject: Only force first letter of fullname to be upper
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-09-26 00:36:40.000000000', 'files': ['doc/source/ocata_ptl_candidates.rst', 'openstack_election/utils.py', 'doc/source/ocata_ptl_results.rst'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/election/commit/d461c157afb574ee4b3ef7cdac349bfa6798c7e8', 'message': 'Only force first letter of fullname to be upper

This change enforce the first and last component
of a fullname to start with an uppercase letter.
This is to keep user's custom capitalisation such as:

* middle name should be lower-case
* keep in-middle uppercase such as "McGinnis"

Change-Id: Ifdad9f05c0d74d18396e9b06bd57c1c0f391be8d
'}]
commit_message:
Only force first letter of fullname to be upper

This change enforce the first and last component
of a fullname to start with an uppercase letter.
This is to keep user's custom capitalisation such as:

* middle name should be lower-case
* keep in-middle uppercase such as "McGinnis"

Change-Id: Ifdad9f05c0d74d18396e9b06bd57c1c0f391be8d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/election refs/changes/58/376058/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Skip some OSTF tests for upgrade thread

We need to skip tests "Check that required services are running"
and "Instance live migration" for the upgrade test because
the compute node still is marked as compute host in OpenStack
cloud in case of the deletion of this compute host from a cluster

Related-Bug: #1627713

Change-Id: I5db681b0eadf09f1f824b5186c2e4aad87faa059

commit_message:

We need to skip tests "Check that required services are running"
and "Instance live migration" for the upgrade test because
the compute node still is marked as compute host in OpenStack
cloud in case of the deletion of this compute host from a cluster

Related-Bug: #1627713

commit_message:
Skip some OSTF tests for upgrade thread

We need to skip tests "Check that required services are running"
and "Instance live migration" for the upgrade test because
the compute node still is marked as compute host in OpenStack
cloud in case of the deletion of this compute host from a cluster

Related-Bug: #1627713

Change-Id: I5db681b0eadf09f1f824b5186c2e4aad87faa059

commit_message:
Add capability to pull in additional quickstart.sh settings

This enables using full-deploy.sh with both downstream CI, as well
as interactive usage for various developer scenarios where one
might wish to pass additional parameters to quickstart.sh

OPT_ADDITIONAL_PARAMETERS will be set to "" only if not defined

Change-Id: I7b697ef289e8b87e10187b158b4b6d2aa4080385

commit_message:
Use assertEqual() instead of assertDictEqual()

In unittesttools, assertDictEqual() and assertEqual()
are implemented by using '!=' operator. But assertEqual()
can handle dict, list, set and so on. So we just call
assertEqual() to make the tests simpler.

Change-Id: I2fdae6892abd3c66bb0702d518101f501e05c4e9

commit_message:
Adding John Davidge candidacy for TC

Change-Id: If7f5b035263a30c0663d98bde0cf24790d19bd21
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/election refs/changes/89/376389/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Hi everyone, I’d like to submit my candidacy for the OpenStack Technical Committee. You may know me as john-davidge on IRC. I’ve been an active member of the OpenStack community since 2012 (Folsom). I met many of you for the first time while presenting the Curvature Network Visualization Dashboard[1] at the Grizzly Summit in Portland. Since then I’ve been working 100% upstream, mostly in neutron[2][3], and for a couple of different sponsors. Right now I’m employed in the OpenStack Innovation Center (OSIC) - a joint venture between Rackspace and Intel - where I’m leading a small team contributing to neutron, and helping to shape the OSIC development roadmap. Over the years I have seen and participated in a lot of the changes that have led our community to where it is today. I’ve experienced the things that have improved our lives as developers, and operators, as well as the things that have caused us difficulties. I know where I would like to see OpenStack head in the future, and I feel strongly about making it a success. The most important thing that I would like to see changed is the overarching framework under which all of OpenStack operates: The Big Tent. Last year, the TC moved OpenStack away from the Integrated Release, and into The Big Tent. This removed the separation between those projects considered integral to OpenStack, and those which enhance it. Since then, the number of official projects has gone from ~12 to 60. While this was a fantastic move for community inclusivity, it has also made life harder for operators and customers, and has diminished the focus on OpenStack’s core purpose. Managing every team under one roof has led to issues for both the core and the newer projects. The experience so far has taught us that there isn’t a single set of rules that can be helpfully applied to both. I believe that now is the time to take The Big Tent’s ideas and iterate upon them to create a new model that can promote inclusivity, while still preserving a clear focus for the core of OpenStack. The main points of this new model are: * Define OpenStack as its core components * Introduce a new home for complementary projects - The OpenStack Family * Reinstate Stackforge as the primary incubator for new projects OpenStack will once again be a focused set of closely aligned projects working together to provide an operating system for the datacenter. The OpenStack Family will provide a home for projects that work to improve the experience of an OpenStack cloud (think Ceilometer, Heat, etc), while protecting them from some of the more prescriptive rules that go with being a core OpenStack component. Stackforge will be the main focus of early-stage innovation, with a clearly defined path towards graduation into The OpenStack Family. I believe that this model[4] can go a long way towards solving many of the pain points that we are seeing with OpenStack today. This transformation is one that I think is very important for the future of OpenStack. We have a fantastic project surrounded by a talented community, of which I am very proud to call myself a member. Trust me with your vote, and I’ll work hard to ensure its continued success. Thank you for your consideration, John [1] https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pmpRhcwyJIo - Curvature [2] https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GjuF-3fB0IQ - IPv6 Prefix Delegation [3] https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4ag1NiCVBDo - Neutron Purge [4] https://johndavidge.wordpress.com/mr-openstack-tear-down-this-tent/

commit_message:
Handle loopback shares without mounting them

Mounting loopback highly available shares is not supported. For
this reason, the previous approach checking whether a share is
local is incorrect.

This patch changes this, attempting to resolve the share address.

Closes-Bug: #1580122
Depends-On: I04ac0b514ccac9c910728da205f0f0f11b43509a
Change-Id: I557c8882dbe45714011d1155dfd553aefafd13e2
(cherry picked from commit c0f5126d62857e3d7258b32e90e3aa0fc5302f84)

commit_message:
Adding constraints around qemu-img calls

* All "qemu-img info" calls are now run under resource limitations
  that limit CPU time to 2 seconds and address space usage to 1 GB.
  This helps avoid any DoS attacks via malicious images.
* All "qemu-img convert" calls now specify the import format so that
  it does not have to be inferred by qemu-img.

SecurityImpact

Change-Id: Ib900bbc05cb9ccd90c6f56ccb4bf2006e30cdc80
Closes-Bug: #1449062
(cherry picked from commit 69a9b659fd48aa3c1f84fc7bc9ae236b6803d31f)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance refs/changes/34/377734/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # NOTE(hemanthm): Asserting that the source format is passed # to qemu-utis to avoid inferring the image format. This # shields us from an attack vector described at # https://bugs.launchpad.net/glance/+bug/1449062/comments/72 self.assertIn('-f', exc_mock.call_args[0]) # NOTE(hemanthm): Asserting that the source format is passed # to qemu-utis to avoid inferring the image format when # converting. This shields us from an attack vector described # at https://bugs.launchpad.net/glance/+bug/1449062/comments/72 # # A total of three calls will be made to 'execute': 'info', # 'convert' and 'info' towards introspection, conversion and # OVF packaging respectively. We care about the 'convert' call # here, hence we fetch the 2nd set of args from the args list. convert_call_args, _ = exc_mock.call_args_list[1] self.assertIn('-f', convert_call_args)
